script_english_words:
The louse whisked himself.

He whisked himself long and hard.

The baby louse splashed water on the rocks

and the louse laughed to his little self.

The louse whisked himself.

He whisked himself long and hard.

The baby louse splashed water on the rocks

and the louse laughed to his little self.
script_alutiiq_words:
Neresta taarimallria.

Taarirpaguarluni.

Ingqim yaamat ciqiluki.

Neresta englaruarluni.

Neresta taarimallria.

Taarirpaguarluni.

Ingqim yaamat ciqiluki.

Neresta englaruarluni.
notes:
This is a traditional song that tells a silly story of lice washing in the banya! The song translates to: The louse whisked himself, he whisked himself long and hard. The baby louse splashed water on the rocks and the louse laughed to his little self. This song was taught to us by our late chief and elder Larry Matfay. 

Transcribed by Jeff Leer, courtesy of the Alutiiq Museum. Generations CD Track 16.

script_english_words:
Puqisqat, nallunrailngut PiRsiitam saaRia'i 

nallun'irluku kangirciluku

nunami suucia qilam Angayuqsinaa 

tanqisqamen agyamen ang'at'slluteng, 

t'killuku Wefliyemaq,

asinrit pikiyutkateng ang'at'slluki, 

suulutaaq cali laataq cali mingugtuutaq; 

igs'piarluteng nayangarluteng 

tang'rhngamegt'gu qaiqunami Inarngallria: 

Uswillraaq Uksuilnguq!
script_alutiiq_words:
The smart, wise kings of Persia recognizing and understanding

that the king of heaven was born

had themselves borne toward the holy star, arrived at Bethlehem,

bearing their best gifts,

gold and frankincense and myrrh; they fell down and worshipped

when they saw Him lying in the cave: the Ageless Child!

script_english_words:
These schooners are making me cry, 

because of my boyfriend. 

What am I going to do afterwards 

they are taking my boyfriend 

away (by boat).
script_alutiiq_words:
Ukut skuunat gui qiagkwaraatnga 

tan'uraruaqa piteklluku. 

Qa'i-cin kinguatni 

piciqsaanga tan'uraruaqa 

aiwilluku.
notes: Original song 'These Schooners' remembered and taught courtesy of Mary Peterson and Jennie Zeeder of Akhiok. Transcription by April Laktonen Counceller, Florence Pestrikoff and Nick Alokli, courtesy of the Alutiiq Museum. Generations CD Tracks 1 and 25. Choreographed at Kodiak Alutiiq Week 2015.

script_english_words:
I am here. I am here. Bashful. Bashful.

Over there. Over there. Bashful. Bashful.

Over there, also. 

All of us. All of us.

Bashful. Bashful. Eyes. Eyes.
script_alutiiq_words:
Gui gwani. Gui gwani. Qikitaq. Qikitaq.

Gui gwani. Gui gwani. Qikitaq. Qikitaq.

Ikani, cali.

Guangkuta. Guangkuta.

Qikitaq. Qikitaq. Iingalak. Iingalak.
notes: This song is about being bashful. The song says I am bashful, the ones of there are bashful, everyone has bashful, bashful eyes. This song was written by our elder Irene Coyle. Transcription by Alisha Drabek.

script_english_words:
Tonight, tonight I will come.

Bring a little tea with me.

If doggies, doggies bark at me.

Don't you think I'm the boogie man!
script_alutiiq_words:
Unuku, unuku taiciqua.

Caayungcugmek tailluanga.

Piugtet, Piugtet qilukaatnga.

Aulaq aulaq pin'illtkicaa!
notes:
This song was given to us by our late chief and elder Larry Matfay. This song is an old Alutiiq Song that we sing in Alutiiq, English and Russian. The Russian Version was taught by Duty Wolkoff. 

Traditional  Tonight' song, shared by Larry Matfay.
Transcription by April Laktonen Counceller, courtesy of the Alutiiq Museum. Generations CD Track 8.

*Alternative pronunciation variation  Arularauyukllua'.
Three verses emphasize the three ways of saying Dogs - Aikut (N); Piugtet (S); Sapakat (R)

script_english_words:
[Follow the ABC song tune for the Alutiiq Alphabet]
Thank you! Sing all you people! 
And all of you sing again!
script_alutiiq_words:
A, C, E, F, G, Gw, Hm, 
Hn, Hng, I, K, Kw,
L, LL, M, N,
Ng, P, Q, r, R, S,
T, U, W, cali Y
Quyanaa! Aturci sugni!
Cali atuungqigtaa'aluci!
notes:
Sung to the tune of  ABC song'
Written by Kathy Nelson with John  JP' Pestrikoff, courtesy of Native Village of Port Lions

script_english_words:
Mom and Dad
made akutaq in a dish
Then Kuukuwak (baby) came in
And ate up all the akutaq
Mom and dad then
and they had to just lick the dish!

Dad & Mom
made akutaq in a dish
Then the baby came in
and they had to just eat the akutaq! Then the baby came in
and they had to just lick the dish! 
Afterwards they licked the bowl.
script_alutiiq_words:
Maamankuk taata-llu 
alutakun akullutek 
Kuukuwak tailuni  
akutallraq piturluku! 
Maamankuk taata-llu 
Kingullrani alutalleq alungluku

Taatan-kuk Maama-llu alutakun akullutek
Kuukuwak tailuni akutallraq pitekluku!
Kuukuwak tailuni akutallraq alungluku! 
Kingullrani alutartek alungluku
notes: This song was taught by Larry Matfay. It is an old Alutiiq Song that tells the story of a family making Akutaq. The story goes that the mother and father were stirring the akutaq in a bowl then the baby of the family came in, ate up all the akutaq and mom and dad only got to lick the bowl!

credit: April Laktonen Counceller, Florence Pestrikoff, Nick Alokli, Susan Malutin
script_english_words:
Inglulgen Agyat cungasqami 

Alas'kaam flagaa umyaaqlluku 

Cungasqaq imaq, unum qilaa 

Ingrit nanwat, suit'kaat cali. 

Suulutanek qawangurtuataallriit. 

Ik'gt'sqaq suulutaq nunamek. 

Akisqat agyat pamani et'sqat. 

Taquka'aq, Qalutaq, akirluteng. 

Agyasinaq cimirtaanisqaq

nuna cali imaq akirt'sluku. 

Alas'kaam flagaa qunukarpet. 

Piarait'sqaq flak Alas'kaamek!
script_alutiiq_words:
Eight stars on blue

Alaska's flag makes you think of

The blue ocean, the night's sky,

The mountains, lakes, and the flowers.

The gold they used to always dream about, The rare gold from the land,

The bright stars located up there

The Bear, The Dipper, they are shining.

The big star that never changes

the land and sea it shines upon.

Alaska's flag that we love.

The simple flag from Alaska!

script_english_words:
Gui gwani pikiyutaq

Imarmek pikiyutamken

Llatuumluni pisurtuq iimiulluku 

Tukniluni pisurtuq

Suuget nerkwarluki

Ugalluku pisurtuq

Atam cali, Atam cali unguwaqa 

pisurtam tunuwaqa.
script_alutiiq_words:
I am here as a gift

From the sea I give you a gift

Knowledgeably he hunts with good aim 

He is a strong hunter

He provides food for the people

From the sea I give you a gift

He is a good hunter

And so, and so, my life

the hunter (respectfully) takes it.

script_english_words:
We are bucking the waves. 

I am remembering, I am remembering. 

We are bucking the waves. 

I am remembering, I am remembering. 

In our seine 

bucking the waves 

ah-ha-ha, ah-ha-ha 

the whale surfaced. 

(killer whale, sea lion, seal)
script_alutiiq_words:
Asgurluta ah-ha-ha. 

Umiaqaqa, umiaqaqa. 

Asgurluta ah-ha-ha. 

Umiaqaqa, umiaqaqa. 

Kugyasirtanemni. 

Asgurluta ag'ngamta 

ah-ha-ha, ah-ha-ha 

ar'uq suart'llria. 

(arlluk, wiinaq, isuwiq) 

(replace repeat)
notes: Lena Amason Berns wrote this song with the help of Papa George Inga and Paul Kahutak, and Stella Krumry of Old Harbor. A fisherman had gone salmon seining and came back with this story.  It was windy! Bucking the waves all day! Not much fish! But I saw a whale surface, a sealion, a killer whale, and a seal!  So I took that little story to Papa George Inga and abolik Kahutak, to find the fishing words in Alutiiq Stephen Blanchette helped us come up with the motions.

script_english_words:
Atgurts'kut qacauski aigaten

Atgurts'kut qacauski aigaten

Atgurts'kut ginarp'ni nunaniqsaagciqukut 

Atgurt'skut qacauski aigaten
script_alutiiq_words:
If you are happy, clap your hands 

If you are happy, clap your hands

If you are happy, and your face shows it, we will all be happy

If you are happy, clap your hands

script_english_words:
Cama'i, unuarpak. 

Cama'i, unuarpak.

Asirtuten-qaa? 

Asirtuten-qaa?

Asirtua, quyanaa. 

Asirtua, quyanaa.

Cestun et'cit? 

Cestun et'cit?
script_alutiiq_words:
Welcome, this morning. 

Welcome, this morning.

Are you good? (How are you?) 

Are you good? (How are you?)

I'm good, thank you.

I'm good, thank you.

How are you? 

How are you?
notes: Sung to the tune of 'Frere Jacques'

script_english_words:
Thank you, thank you.
Thank you [that] you all came.
We are happy, we are happy.
We are happy [that] you all came.
[chanting]
We are proudly happy.
[chanting],
[that] you all came.
[chanting], 
we are proudly happy.

Quyanaa, Quyanaa,
Quyanaa, tailuci.
Silugtukut, silugtukut,
Silugtukut tailuci.
ayangaa, ayangaa, ayangaa
Silugtukut.
ay'angaa, ay'angaa, ay'angaa,
Tailuci.
ay'angaa, ay'angaa, ay'angaa,
Silugtukut.
notes: Original song by Mary Haakanson, Sperry Ash, with the Academy of Elders at Dig Afognak, 1999.

script_english_words:
In Kodiak, like those who came from a long time ago!

We are dancing we are dancing!

We are singing we are singing!

We are having fun!
script_alutiiq_words:
Sun'ami cumillat'stun taiyukut.

Agnguarluta, agnguarluta.

Aturluta, aturluta.

Nunaniqsaagluta
notes: We the people of Kodiak are doing just like our Ancestors did a long time ago, dancing and singing

script_english_words:
My drum.
I found it.
Come [all].
To listen to it.
My dance
I found it.
Let's go!
Come join us.

We did not travel far.
We did not travel.
We found them inside ourselves.
It was always in our hearts.
Our ancestors are happy.
script_alutiiq_words:
Cauyaqa hey ya hey ya.
Gui ikuk'gka nga hey ya.
Tailuci hey ya hey ya.
Nit'niqlluku nga hey ya.
Agnguaqa hey ya hey ya.
Gui ikuk'gka  nga hey ya.
Kita-ruq! 
ilag'rutlluta.

Natmen ag'n'illriakut yaqgwanun. 
Natmen ag'n'illriakut hey ya hey ya (chorus)
Guangkupt'hni ilumt'hni ikuk'gpet. 
Qangiq unguwatemt'hni et'llria. 
Guangkuta cuumillall'pet silugtut! (chorus)
notes: This song was written by Loren Anderson. It is a story about a lost drum, and when finding it, realizing that the music had been inside them all along. Featured on the Generations CD by the Alutiiq Museum, Track 19. Loren grew up near Seattle, Washington. In Washington, he had very little exposure to his Sugpiat heritage. When he moved to Alaska, he began working at the Alaska Native Heritage Center, where he learned more about his culture. He also joined an Alutiiq dance group called the Alutiiq Anguyiit or the Alutiiq Warriors. Cauyaqa Gwi Ikuk'gka is the first song Loren wrote, and it's about metaphorically finding his drum. The drum represents his entire Alutiiq heritage, and he had found that his culture has always been within him.

credit: Alutiiq Language Club and the Alutiiq Museum
script_english_words:
Today is your birthday.

Today is your birthday.

I'm happy you were born, (name).

You have a lot of fun, (too)!
script_alutiiq_words:
Ernerpak suucillran.

Ernerpak suucillran.

Atgurtua suullriaten,

Nunaniqsaakina!
notes: Sung to the tune of Happy Birthday

script_english_words:
We are getting up. We are getting up.

Here are many people. Here are many people.

We have to get together as one,

That way we will be strong.

If we stay together as one, helping each other,

that way we will be strong people.

We won't have a hard time.

If we do this we can be happy/proud ourselves.

(chanting, and then stomp 3x)
script_alutiiq_words:
Ugai. Ugai.

Gua sugpakat. Gua sugpakat.

Katurt'kaukut allringurmen,

tawaten tuknigciqukut.

Ellkumta allringu'uluta, ikayulluta,

Tuknignayartukut sugni.

Kayagyugninaitukut.

Tawatarluta taumi silugnayartukut guangkumt'nek.

m'mm, m'mm

m'mm, m'mm (stomp 3x)
notes: Written and shared by Sperry Ash of Nanwalek. We adapted the song to the Koniag Dialect with Sperry's permission. Ugai is a song about the strength of our people. It says that when we are together, helping each other, we will be stronger and will not have a hard time. Kodiak Alutiiq language adjustments by Alisha Drabek, Susan Malutin, Florence Pestrikoff, Sophie Shepherd, Kathryn Chichenoff, and Nick Alokli.

script_english_words:
You all come in your kayaks.

Paddle and paddle (row).

Arrow, arrow.

Arrow, arrow.

Arrow, arrow.

We got it!
script_alutiiq_words:
Tailuci qayakun.

Anguarluci.

Ruuwaq, ruuwaq.

Ruuwaq, ruuwaq.

Ruuwaq, ruuwaq.

Pitakarpet!
notes: Come by kayak, paddle and paddle, we will pick up our arrows and go hunting and if we are lucky we will be successful hunters. This song was given by the late elder Nina Olsen.

script_english_words:
Come my friends, 

let's all go sledding, let's all go sledding. 

Come my friends, 

let's all go sledding, let's all go sledding.

Beautifully, the snow is falling. 

Beautifully, the snow is falling. 

Enough, let's go, enough!
script_alutiiq_words:
Tailuci angayumang, 

lluuwarlita, lluuwarlita. 

Tailuci angayumang, 

lluuwarlita, lluuwarlita. 

Cucunarluni, aniuq katagtuq. 

Cucunarluni, aniuq katagtuq. 

Awa'i, aglita, awa'i!

script_english_words:
Once upon a time a warrior 

his spear would help us. (2x) 

(Chanting) 

When we were doing our daily activity the spear was stolen. 

Although those of us have we will never forget it the spear is our identity. 

We will grab the spear 

and never let it go 

because we are Sugpiaq!
script_alutiiq_words:
Aka tamani anguyaghten 

kapu'uu'tiin Ikallyullruakut. 

Aya'aa ha'aya 

Yung'ii nanempteni Kapuun teglegaat. 

Taugwaam guangkuta Nalluygucunaku. 

Kapuun paitaqerput 

guankut tumakiiluat 

pegcunaku Sugpiaruluten!
notes: Song written by Stephen Blanchett and the Alaska Native Heritage Center Dancers of the time. The song retells a story that Lucille Davis would tell about a spear that fought in a battle against the Russians, that hung above the doorway. While they were out gathering, the spear was taken. The spear was remade by Michael Livingston of the Aleutians, and gifted to Lucille and her family, along with this song.

script_english_words:
It's snowing. It's snowing. It's snowing. 

It's snowing. It's snowing. It's snowing. 

Three of them big 

from snow, let's make a ball. 

And then into one, 

put them, make a man.
script_alutiiq_words:
Qaninguq. Qaninguq. Qaninguq. 

Qaninguq. Qaninguq. Qaninguq.  

Pingayunek angluki, 

aniumek mayaciilita. (2x) 

Taumi allrilugmen, 

lliiluki, suarliluta. (2x)
notes: This is our snowman song. It is snowing, we will make three large snowballs, stack them to make our snowmen, then put on the eyes, mouth, nose and buttons then kick them down. This song was written by Stella Krumrey. Generations CD Track 2.

script_english_words:
Thank you for coming. 

Thank you for coming. 

Alaskans, and strangers. 

On the other side of the Alaskan mountain. 

Thank you very much, for all coming. 

Ah ah, oh oh, We'll see you all. 

Ah ah, oh oh, We'll see you all. 

Ah ah, oh oh, We'll see you all. 

Forgive yourself.
script_alutiiq_words:
Quyanaa Tailuci. 

Quyanaa Tailuci. 

Alas'kaarmiut allanertat, cali. 

Alas'kaam ingrim akiani. 

Quyanaarpak, quyanaarpak tailuci. 

Ah ah, oh oh.  Tang'rciqamci. 

Ah ah, oh oh.  Tang'rciqamci. 

Ah ah, oh oh.  Tang'rciqamci. 

PRastiirluten.
notes: Original 'Thank you for coming' song by Irene Coyle, featured on the Generations CD

script_english_words:
Thank you all for inviting us. 

We hope you enjoyed our performance. 

Our journey with you is coming to an end. 

The Kodiak Alutiiq Dancers 

are thankful to you all 

for coming.
script_alutiiq_words:

Pingar'ci. 

Ellpeci-llu caqaiput taqutut. 

Sun'aq Alutiit Agngaursqat 

quyawiklluci 

tailuten.

script_english_words:
I'm climbing on top of it. I'm hunting for puffins. 

Heading up there, I am climbing. 

I arrive at their dens. 

I'm climbing on top of it. I'm climbing on top of it. 

I'm hunting for puffins.
script_alutiiq_words:
Ugtua. Ugtua. Tunngargsurtua. 

Paagut Mayurtua. 

Tekigatanka legtiat. 

Ugtua. Ugtua. 

Tunngargsurtua.

script_english_words:
Ay-ya, ay-ya, I just remember it. 



Long ago If 

I was (lived) here, I was (lived) here. 

On the ocean 

fishing. 



These days (now) I 

I am (always) here, I am (always) here 

In my mind 

Fishing. 



Later, my family 

Will be here, will be here  

On the ocean 

They will have fun 



Ya-ha, Ya-ha, Ya-ha-hey! (Chanting)
script_alutiiq_words:
Ay-ya, ay-ya, umiaqartaqa. X2 



Qangiq Gui

Etaallianga, etaallianga 

Imarmi 

Iqallugsurlua. 



(Chorus) 

Nutaan Gui

Etartuanga, etaartuanga 

Umiamni  

Iqallugsurlua. 



(Chorus) 

Ilanka Atakuu, 

Etarrciqut, etaarciqut 

Imarmi 

Nunaniqsaagciqut 



(Chorus) 

Ya-ga, Ya-ga, Ya-ga-gai
notes: Written by April Laktonen Counceller with help from Nick Alokli, Theresa John, Agatha John Shields, Desiree Cronin-Tallman in 2010. Choreographed by Brandi, Baskofsky, Allison Anderson, and April Laktonen Counceller. Song shares the story of a person who used to go fishing all the time and they now fish in their mind, but someday her family will have fun on the water someday.

credit: Florence Pestrikoff, Kari Sherod, Lena Amason, and Agatha John-Sheilds
script_english_words:
I was sitting, I hear something 
the land here is moving. 
It is getting stronger. 

(Chorus)
I was sitting, I hear something 
the land here is moving. 
It is getting stronger. 

I look for my children. 
We climb the mountain. 
The great wave pulls away our houses. 
The land here is moving. 
It is getting stronger. 

My children are all together (as one) 
Being thankful to God. 
The land here is moving. 
It is getting stronger.

I was sitting, I hear something 
the land here is moving. 
It is getting stronger.
script_alutiiq_words:
Aqum'allianga caqiq niitaqa. 
Aqum'allianga caqiq niitaqa. 
Man'a nuna arulaluni/ aulaluni 
Tuknitmen agluni. Yi-ii-ii-ii-rii. 

(Chorus) 
Aqum'allianga caqiq niitaqa. 
Man'a nuna arulaluni/ aulaluni. 
Tuknitmen agluni. Yi-ii-ii-ii-rii. 

Uswillranka iwa'iluki. 
Mayurluta ingrimen. 
Qangyusinaq unglupet* cayugluki. 
Man'a nuna arulaluni/ aulaluni. 
Tuknitmen agluni. Yi-ii-ii-ii-rii. 

Uswillranka allrilurmi. 
Quyawakilluku Agayun. 
Man'a nuna arulaluni/ aulaluni. 
Tuknitmen agluni. Yi-ii-ii-ii-rii. 

Aqum'allianga caqiq niitaqa. 
Aqum'allianga caqiq niitaqa. 
Man'a nuna arulaluni/ aulaluni 
Tuknitmen agluni. Yi-ii-ii-ii-rii.
notes: By Florence Pestrikoff, Kari Sherod, Lena Amason, and Agatha John-Shields with help from Nick Alokli and Dennis Knagin. Inspired by Florence's experience of the 1964 Earthquake and Tidal Wave in Old Harbor. Englupet is the northern word for house, but this song was written from Florence's experience and 'ungluq' is the way she says house.

script_english_words:
You are my sun(shine), 

My only sun(shine), 

You make me happy when it's overcast. 

You will never know, 

How I love you, 

Don't take my sun(shine) away. 



The day before yesterday, 

when I was sleeping, 

in my dream I was holding you. 

Then I woke up, 

I made a mistake 

I felt sad, then I cried.
script_alutiiq_words:
Ellpet macaqa 

Kisiin macaqa, 

Atgurt'starp'nga talumakan, 

Nalluciqan, 

Cestun qunukamken, 

Macaqa tun'illkiu gwamnek. 



Akgua'am yatiini 

qawarngama, 

qawangumni tuumiaq'gkemken. 

Taumi esgarngama, 

Alart'llrumaunga,

Imasuugllianga, qiawagcaa.
notes:
Translation of You Are My Sunshine. Students at Dig Afognak Language and Music Camp 2014 developed the dance movements to the song. 
Sung to the tune of 'You are My Sunshine'. Transcription by April Laktonen Counceller, Shauna Hegna, Florence Pestrikoff & Nick Alokli, courtesy of the Alutiiq Museum. Generations CD Track 5.

script_english_words:
Four boats are swaying.

Sugar, coffee, 

put them in the cupboard. 

They might fall out. 

Sing. 



Four boats are swaying. 

We take off our boots and sit down. 

Sugar, coffee, 

Put them in the cupboard. 

They might fall out. 

Sing.

SaagaRaq, kuugiaq, 

Skaapamen lliiluki. 

Katagsuartut. 

Aturluki. 



Staaman palayat arulatai.   X2 

ARapaci yuuluki aqumluci. 

Kuugiaq, saagaRaq, 

skaapamen lliiluki. 

Katagsuartut. 

Aturluki.
notes: Verse two as sung by Larry Matfay, recording courtesy of the Alutiiq Museum. Transcribed by April Laktonen Counceller with edits by Alisha Drabek and Peter Squartsoff.

script_english_words:
The sun is getting hot. 

It is summer. 



Summer birds are singing (humming) 

Yellow crown sparrow we hear it (humming) 

The sun is getting hot 

It is summer 



Summer sea birds we see them (humming) 

The bumble bees are coming (humming) 

The sun is getting hot 

It is summer 



Dragon flies are flying (humming) 

Mosquitoes are buzzing (humming) 

The sun is getting hot 

It is summer

Kiagtuq 



Saqullkanat aturtut hm, hm, hm 

Ikuwitiit niitarpet hm, hm, hm 

Macaq uqnaiyuq X2 

Kiagtuq 



Cuwat tangrapet hm hm hm 

Uuqutiit taiyut hm hm hm 

Macaq uqnaiyuq X2 

Kiagtuq 



Cilrayut tengaurtut hm hm hm 

Mengquilut em'irtut hm hm hm 

Macaq uqnaiyuq X2  

Kiagtuq

script_english_words:
Thank you all for coming, Alutiiq people. 

Thank you all for coming, visitors. 

Thank you all for coming, Alutiiq people.

Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. 

for coming, for coming, Father. 

for coming, for coming, Son of Man. 

for coming, for coming, Spirit of God. 

Thank you. Thank you. Thank you.
script_alutiiq_words:
Quyanaa tailuci, Sugpiat. 

Quyanaa tailuci, allanertat. 

Quyanaa tailuci, Sugpiat. 

Quyanaa. Quyanaa. Quyanaa. (2x) 

Tailuten, Tailuten, Taata. 

Tailuten, Tailuten, Awaqutan. (2x) 

Tailuten, Tailuten, Anerneran. 

Quyanaa. Quyanaa. Quyanaa. (2x)
notes: Original song by June Pardue, with Alutiiq editorial assistance from Florence Pestrikoff. Performed as a welcome dance, welcoming all of the audience members to the performance, inviting everyone to come and watch.

script_english_words:
The old man is hunting. 
He sees a bear!
And now he stands up...
He pulls back his arrow.
Here's a bear,
there's a bear,
here, there
Bears all around.
The old man is hunting.
He got it!
script_alutiiq_words:
Angutaq pisurtuq. 
Taquka'aq tangraa!
Nutaan-llu nangartuq...
Ruuwaq cayugaa.
Gwaa'i taquka'aq,
tawa'i taquka'aq.
Gwani, tawani.
Taqukaraat tamiini.
Angutaq pisurtuq.
Pitaqaa!
notes: Original  He is hunting' song, sung to the tune of  Old McDonald Had a Farm,' by Irene Coyle and Alisha Drabek. Replace an animal name to sing a new verse. Recording courtesy of the Alutiiq Museum. Generations CD Track 11.

script_english_words:
I'm a little teapot, 
Short and stout. 
Here is my handle. 
Here is my spout. 

When I start to boil [get all steamed up], 
Hear me [shout],
[Just]  Tip me over,
And then pour me out.'
script_alutiiq_words:
Gui caininguangcuk, 
Nanitua lurtulua. 
Gwaa'i aigaqa. 
Gwaa'i kugwika. 

Gui qallakuma,
Niicikarp'nga. 
 Kitngullua, 
Taumi kuglua.'
notes: Sung to the tune of  I'm a little teapot,' transcribed by Alisha Drabek with translations by Qik'tarmiut Alutiit Language Club Elders

credit: April Laktonen Counceller, Florence Pestrikoff & Nick Alokli
script_english_words:
The itsy bitsy spider 
climbed up the water's pipe. 
And then it started to rain, 
the spider slid away.
And then the sun came out, 
it dried up the rain. 
And then the itsy bitsy spider
climbed up the pipe again.
script_alutiiq_words:
Miktengcusqaq miskiiRaq* 
mayukii taangam paipaa. 
Taumi qitenguartaa, 
miskiiRaq llurluni. 
Taumi macaq suarluni,
qiteq kinert'sluku.
Taumi miktengcuusqaq miskiiRaq*
paipaq mayungqiskii.
notes:
Sung to the tune of  'Itsy Bitsy Spider' by April Laktonen Counceller, Florence Pestrikoff & Nick Alokli, courtesy of the Alutiiq Museum. 
* Alternative Northern Alutiiq pronunciation of  miskiiRaq' or  spider' is  miskiiRiaq'.

credit: Qik'rtarmiut Alutiit Program Masters and Apprentices
script_english_words:
Rain, rain, go away. 
Come again another day. 
We want to play today. 
Come again in the fall. 

Rain, rain, go away.
Come again another day.
The fish in the river
They are coming, they are laying their eggs.
script_alutiiq_words:
Qiteq, qiteq, awasaa. 
Taisumuten atakuu. 
Wamyugtukut ernerpak. 
Taisumuten uksuarku. 

Qiteq, qiteq, awasaa. 
Taisumuten atakuu.
Iqalluk kuigmen
Tairyugtut, siisuten angcugrait.
notes: Sung to the tune of  Rain Rain Go Away,' translated by Qik'rtarmiut Alutiit ...

credit: April Laktonen Counceller, Florence Pestrikoff, Nick Alokli
script_english_words:
One, Two, Three Alutiit. 
Four, Five, Six Alutiit. 
Seven, Eight, Nine Alutiit. 
Ten little Alutiit. 

Ten, Nine, Eight Alutiit. 
Seven, Six, Five Alutiit. 
Four, Three, Two Alutiik.
 One little Alutiiq.
script_alutiiq_words:
Allringuq, Mal'uk, Pingayun Alutiit. 
Staaman, Talliman, Arwilgen Alutiit. 
Mallruungin, Inglulgen, Qulnguyan Alutiit. 
Qulen Alutiingcut. 

Qulen, Qulnguyan, Inglulgen Alutiit. 
Mallruungin, Arwilgen, Talliman Alutiit. 
Staaman, Pingayun, Mal'uk Alutiik. 
Allringuq Alutiingcuk.
notes:
Sung to the tune of  Ten Little Indians'
Courtesy of the Alutiiq Museum, April Laktonen Counceller, Florence Pestrikoff and Nick Alokli originally developed in the village of Old Harbor. 
Alternative pronunciation for  One' - Allriluq

script_english_words:
The ocean is really blue. 
The land is green. 
Summer makes me happy. 
I like summer. 
Many summers. 
Many summers. 
Many summers.
script_alutiiq_words:
Imaq cungagpiartuq. 
Nuna cungaguartuq.
 Kiam atgurt'staanga. 
Kiak pingakaqa. 
Amlertut kiaget. 
Amlertut kiaget. 
Amlertut kiaget.
notes: Recording courtesy of the Alutiiq Museum. Generations CD Track 4. Recording courtesy of the Alutiiq Museum. Generations CD Track 4.

script_english_words:
Thank you. Thank you for all coming. 
Thank you. Thank you for all coming. 
I will see you all. I will see you all sometime. 
We are returning to Old Harbor. 

Thank you. Thank you for all coming. 
Thank you. Thank you for all coming.
I will see you all. I will see you all sometime.
We all had fun.
script_alutiiq_words:
Quyanaa, Quyanaa taigkwarluta. 
Quyanaa, Quyanaa tailuci Tang'rciqamci. 
Tang'rciqamci caminguaku. 
Angiitukut Nuniamen. 

Quyanaa, Quyanaa Taiwarluta. 
Quyanaa, Quyanaa Tailuci Tang'rciqamci. 
Tang'rciqamci caminguaku. 
Nunaniqsaagllriakut.

script_english_words:
We are grateful to Dennis
Thank you in appreciation of Dennis In appreciation of him....
In appreciation of him.... 
In appreciation of him.... 

He is at the beginning of a new journey 
Taking the opportunity to weigh anchor

As you work remember, 
Tonight you will banya
script_alutiiq_words:
Guangkuta Dennis'aq quyaklluku 
Quyanaa Dennis'aq quyaklluku 
Quyaklluku. Quyaklluku. 
Quyaklluku Quyaklluku

Ang'asiigluni cuunga arularnirluni 
Cali tekiulluni kicarlluni

Peklluten umiaqlluku 
Akgua'arpak maqiciquten
notes: by Loren Anderson for Dennis Metrokin, President of Koniag, at his retirement

script_english_words:
Pray in the morning 
Pray in the daytime 
Pray in the evening 
Let your heart be well 

God hears your prayer in the morning 
God hears your prayer in the day 
God hears your prayer in the evening 
And your life will be well 

Christ may come in the morning 
Christ may come in the day 
Christ may come in the evening 
And your life will be well
script_alutiiq_words:
Agayuluten unuami 
Agayuluten ernermi 
Agayuluten akgua'armi 
Unguwan asirt'lluku 

Agayun niitaten unuami 
Agayun niitaten ernermi 
Agayun niitaten akgua'armi 
Unguwan asirt'lluku

KRistuusaaq taikauq unuami 
KRistuusaaq taikauq ernermi 
KRistuusaaq taikauq akgua'armi 
Unguwan asirt'lluku

script_english_words:
Christ is born
Glorify him
Christ in Heaven they see 
To earth Christ was brought 
Everyone sing
All across the land 

And!

Joyfully
Everyone sing and 
Sing again
script_alutiiq_words:
KRistuusaaq suu'uq
Nanrauqicu
KRistuusaaq qilagmi tangraat 
KRistuusaaq nunamen agauskicu 
Aturci sugni cali
Tamarmi nuna

Cali!

Nunaniqsaagluci 
Aturci sugni cali 
Atuungqigtaa'aluci
notes: Russian Starring song in Alutiiq.

script_english_words:
The reindeer are coming. 
Don't be afraid. 
Santa Claus is coming soon. 
ting-a-ling-a-ling (bells ring) 

In the distance he is ringing the bells 
from the mountains he comes
From over there he comes. 
ting-a-ling-a-ling (bells ring)
script_alutiiq_words:
Tuntut taiyut.
Alingn'illkici. 
Santa Claus-eq tainia'artuq. 
ting-a-ling-a-ling 

Akma kuluk'aunat kaugai. 
Ing'igun-ruq taitaartuq. 
Tamaagun-ruq taitaartuq. 
ting-a-ling-a-ling!
notes: Original song courtesy of Sophie Katelnikoff Shepherd, remembered from childhood in Karluk. Transcribed by April Laktonen Councellor, Alutiiq Museum. Generations CD Track 24.

script_english_words:
Head, shoulders, knees and toes.
Knees and toes.
Knees and toes. 
Head, shoulders, knees and toes. Eyes, ears, mouth and nose.
script_alutiiq_words:
Nasquq, tuik*, cisquk, angengquyut**. 
cisquk, angengquyut**.
cisquk, angengquyut**. 
Nasquq, tuik*, cisquk, angengquyut**. Iingalak, cuutek, qaneq, cali qengeq.
notes:
A chant, similar to 'Head, Shoulders, Knees and Toes'. by Sophie Katelnikoff Shepherd and Susie Malutin, with the Alutiiq Language Club. 

*Alternative Southern pronunciation of 'shoulder' - 'tusek; tuwik' ** Alternative Southern Alutiiq use of 'toes' - 'putukut'

title_english: The Bear Went Over the Mountain
script_english_words:
The bear went 
over the mountain.
The bear went
over the mountain.
To see what he will see (What will he see) the other side of the mountain
He is the only one that saw
The other side of the mountain
Was all that he could see
script_alutiiq_words:
Taquka'aq ag'llria (3x) 
ing'im akianun. (3x) 
Taquka'aq ag'llria
ing'im akianun. Caqimek tang'rciquq (3x) ing'im akiani (4x) 
Kesiin tang'rkii (3x) Ing'im akia
Kesiin tang'rkaukii.
notes: Sung to the tune of 'The Bear Went Over the Mountain' courtesy of the Alutiiq Museum Language Club

credit: April Counceller, Florence Pestrikoff, Nick Alokli
script_english_words:
The whale, the whale is swimming in the sea. 
The deer, the deer is climbing the mountain. 
The eagle, the eagle is flying in the sky. 
The bear, the bear is walking on the land. 
The sea lion, the sea lion is laying on the rock!
script_alutiiq_words:
Ar'uq, Ar'uq kuimartuq imarmi. 
Tuntuq, tuntuq mayurtuq ingrimi. 
Kum'agyak, kum'agyak tengaurtuq qilagmi. 
Taquka'aq, taquka'aq kuingtuq nunami. 
Wiinaq, wiinaq inarngauq yaamami!
notes: Original 'Animals' song by April Counceller with help from Florence Pestrikoff and Nick Alokli, courtesy of the Alutiiq Museum Language Program.

script_english_words:
It's snowing. It's snowing. It's snowing. 
It's snowing. It's snowing. It's snowing. 
Three of them, big,
from snow, let's make a ball.
And then into one,
put them, make a man.
script_alutiiq_words:
Qaninguq. Qaninguq. Qaninguq. 
Qaninguq. Qaninguq. Qaninguq. 
Pingayunek angluki,
aniumek mayaciililita. (2x) 
Taumi allrilugmen, 
lliiluki, suarliluta. (2x)
notes: Original 'Snowman' song by Stella Krumrey and the Old Harbor youth, _ recording courtesy of the Alutiiq Museum. Generations CD Track 2.

script_english_words:
We are family.
My brothers, sisters, and me. We are family.
My brothers, sisters, and me. We are family.
Get up everyone and sing. We are family.
My brothers, sisters, and me. We are family.
Get up everyone and sing.
script_alutiiq_words:
I-la-ku-tu-kut.
A-ning-an-ka, al-qan-ka, ca-li gui. I-la-ku-tu-kut.
Nang-ar-ci a-tur-lu-ci. I-la-ku-tu-kut.
A-ning-an-ka, al-qan-ka, ca-li gui. I-la-ku-tu-kut.
Nang-ar-ci a-tur-lu-ci. 

Ilakutukut.
Aninganka, alqanka, cali gui. Ilakutukut.
Nangarci aturluci. Ilakutukut.
Aninganka, alqanka, cali gui. Ilakutukut.
Nangarci aturluci.
notes: Sung to the original 'We are Family' song chorus by Sister Sledge. Translated by Susie Malutin and the Alutiiq Language Club.

credit: Florence Pestrikoff, with April Laktonen Counceller, & Nick Alokli,
script_english_words:
Blink, blink, little star!
How I wonder what you are.
in the heavens you are way up high, diamond you are like
Blink, blink, little star!
How I wonder what you are.
script_alutiiq_words:
Cikmia, cikmia, agyangcuk! 
Kangiilyugtua caqiq ellpet. 
Llaam'i qus'igpiarluten, puup'niiq ayuq'piarluku. 
Cikmia, cikmia, agyangcuk! 
Kangiilyugtua caqiq ellpet.
notes: Sung to the tune of 'Twinkle, Twinkle Little Star'. by Florence Pestrikoff, with April Laktonen Counceller, & Nick Alokli, courtesy of the Alutiiq Museum.

script_english_words:
Six little ducks I once knew
short ones, fat ones, skinny ones too
but the one little duck with a feather on her back 
she led the others with a quack, quack, quack 
quack, quack, quack...quack, quack, quack. 

Down to the river they did go
wibble, wobble, wibble, wobble, ho, ho, ho
but the one little duck with a feather on her back
she led the others with a quack, quack, quack 
quack, quack, quack...quack, quack, quack. 

Home from the river they did come
wibble, wobble, wibble, wobble, ho, ho, ho
but the one little duck with a feather on her back 
she led the others with a quack, quack, quack
quack, quack, quack...quack, quack, quack.
script_alutiiq_words:
Arwilegnek saqul'aangcut nallun'illkenka 
nanit'sqat, quilit'sqat, mayart'sqat cali 
allringuq saqul'aangcuk culuk pequani 
malirkarturluku, [quack, quack, quack] 
[quack, quack, quack...quack, quack, quack]. 
malirkarturluku, [quack, quack, quack] 

Nutaan, aciwarluteng kuigmen
[wibble, wobble, wibble, wobble, ho, ho, ho] 
allringuq saqul'aangcuk culuk pequani 
malirkarturluku, [quack, quack, quack] 
[quack, quack, quack...quack, quack, quack]. 
malirkarturluku, [quack, quack, quack] 

Nutaan, tailuteng kuigmek
[wibble, wobble, wibble, wobble, ho, ho, ho] 
allringuq saqul'aangcuk culuk pequani 
malirkarturluku, [quack, quack, quack] 
[quack, quack, quack...quack, quack, quack]. 
malirkarturluku, [quack, quack, quack]
notes: Translated by Susan Malutin and Sophie Shepherd, with editorial review by Florence Pestrikoff, Mary Haakanson, Nick Alokli, April Laktonen Counceller, and Alisha Drabek. Sung to the tune of 'Six Little Ducks.'

credit: Qik'rtarmiut Alutiit Program Masters and Apprentices
script_english_words:
Silent night, holy night.
It is calm; it is bright.
Over there a young girl with an infant. Holy infant, without sin.
Keep sleeping in comfort...
Keep sleeping in comfort
script_alutiiq_words:
Unuk nepainani, unuk tanqigluni. 
Pinarlluni; Tanqigluni.
Aagani arya'aq carliani-llu. Tanqisqaq Carliaq, kRigaa'inani 
Qawasaa'a tukiluten... 
Qawasaa'a tukiluten
notes: Sung to the tune of 'Silent Night,' translated by Qik'rtarmiut Alutiit Program Masters and Apprentices, courtesy of the Alutiiq Museum. Generations CD Track 12.

script_english_words:
Follow me
Follow me
Follow me
People of the sea
People of the sea
People of the sea
script_alutiiq_words:
Malisnga
Malisnga
Malisnga 
imarmi sugni
imarmi sugni
imarmi sugni

script_english_words:
A new Joy in all our world,
Now God has appeared to us;
He Himself in His glory
is born of Mary in a cave.
The angles up in heaven are in awe of Him;
The people born of the earth, the people now rejoice. 
The shepherds, with wonder plainly visible,
behold one another.
Opening the sky for them,
from the east comes the King. To the Newborn Infant,
All of you here, all of you here, all of you here,
[May you live] for many years.
script_alutiiq_words:
Nuta'aq Quswasuuciq tamiini-i llaamt'hni, 
nutaan gwangkumt'hnun alairtuq A-Agayun; 
Alingnauciminek Ellminek
MaRiamek qa'iqunami suuguq. 
Taugna aan'kilat qilagmi pamani nataqutaraat;
nunam sustellri, suuget nunaniqsaagtut.
Pastuugaat pitegniunaiteng nallunainaki tangrutut,
Ikiyulluki ungalamek Angayuqasinaq taiyuq.
Nuta'armen Suullriamen Uswiillra'armen,
KRistuusamen Agayutmen pikiyutet tailluki
Ellpeci gua'i, ellpeci gua'i, ellpeci gua'i,
Amlesqanun kiagnun.
notes: A New Joy' Traditional Orthodox hymn transcribed and translated by Jeff Leer ,with edits by Alisha Drabek to accompany singing by Sophie Shepherd. Generations CD Tracks 9 & 10.

script_english_words:
Amlertut, Amlertut, Amlertut kiaget. 
Amlertut kiaget
script_alutiiq_words:
Many, Many, Many years (summers) 
Many years (summers)
notes: Many Years' Traditional Orthodox song transcribed by April Laktonen Counceller.

title_english: I Will Tell You a Story
script_english_words:
I will tell you all a story 
All of you face me
I went fishing
And I ate spam! 

An orca surfaced. 
It saw the hook 
Then we went back 
The orca dove. 

(Repeat Chorus) 

The halibut's belly? 
My net I pulled
It took the fish 
Then it dove. 

(Repeat Chorus)
script_alutiiq_words:
Qulianguiciqamci (-qamci). 
tamarpeci caugnga. 
iqallugsurllrianga (-illrianga) 
Taumi nerellia[nga] spam-eq! 

Arlluk suarllria (suarllria). 
Iqsak tang'rkii.
Taumi angillriakuk (-llriakuk) 
Arlluk amllugluni. 

(Repeat Chorus) 

Sagim aqsa-qaa? (aqsa-qaa?). 
Kugyasiqa takungnemgiu. 
Iqalluk tuukii (tuukii) 
Taumi amllugluni. 

(Repeat Chorus)
notes: I will tell you a story' song (AKA Spam-eq) by Peter Squartsoff with help from Florence Pestrikoff, Kathy Nelson, and Theresa John at the Cutmen Agnguartukut Workshop in 2010.

script_english_words:
(Chanting)
It is raining, Father. 
He is fishing
with boys, with boys! 

(Chanting)
It is raining, girls.
They are salmonberry picking 
(Laughing sound), (laughing sound)! 

(Chanting)
It is raining, sea otters. 
They are playing.
Look at them, Look at them!
script_alutiiq_words:
Yang-ag-ya-hai yang-ag-ya-hai 
Qitenguq, Taata. 
Iqallugsurtuq 
tan'urat-llu, tan'urat-llu! 

Yang-ag-ya-hai yang-ag-ya-hai 
Qitenguq, arya'at. 
Alagnarsurtut 
Ya-ga-gai, Ya-ga-gai! 

Yang-ag-ya-hai yang-ag-ya-hai 
Qitenguq, arhnat. 
Waamut.
Tang'rturki, Tang'rturki!
notes: (Sing the 3 verses 2 times) Composed by participates of the Dig Afognak Music Camp 2012.

script_english_words:
My family (chanting) 
Is going (chanting) 
By kayak
(chanting).
It is calm 
(chanting)!

For seal 
(chanting)
I am going to spear it (chanting) 
By kayak
(chanting).
It is calm
(chanting)!
script_alutiiq_words:
Ilanka ay'angaa 
Agllriit ay'angaa, 
Kayagun / Kayakun, 
oh ho oh ho. 
Pinartuq 
oh ho, oh ho, oh ho, oh ho! 

Isuwiq ay'angaa 
Ayaqukutaqa ay'angaa 
Kayagun / Kayakun
oh ho oh ho. 
Pinartuq 
oh ho, oh ho, oh ho, oh ho!
notes: (Sing the 2 verses 2 times) Composed by participates of the Dig Afognak Music Camp 2012.

script_english_words:
It is calm. It is calm.
We are going by boat. We are going by boat. 
Puffins, Puffins,
They are flying around. They are flying around. 
Look at them. Look at them.
and the killer whale is breathing!
It is calm. It is calm.
We are going by boat. We are going by boat!
script_alutiiq_words:
Pinartuq. Pinartuq. 
Aiwiyukut. Aiwiyukut. 
Tunngat, tunngat, 
Tengaurtut. Tengaurtut. 
Tang'rki. Tang'rki. 
Cali arlluk anertkauq! 
Pinartuq. Pinartuq. 
Aiwiyukut. Aiwiyukut!
notes: (Sing 2 times) Composed by participates of the Dig Afognak Music Camp 2012.

script_english_words:
Here is the school. 
Here are the flags. 
Open up the door. 
See all the people. 

Here is the church. 
Here is the cross. 
Open up the door. 
See all the people.
script_alutiiq_words:
Gwaa'i litnaurwik. 
Gwaa'i flaaget. 
Ikirsgu amiik.
Tang'rkii sugpakat.

Gwaa'i agayuwik. 
Gwaa'i kRistaaq. 
Ikirsgu amiik. 
Tang'rkii sugpakat.
notes: This fingerplay is adapted from the English 'Here is the church...'.

credit: Dig Afognak Language and Music Camp, 2013
script_english_words:
Pee-yew!
It's messy in here! 
We all
should clean up. 

First the outhouses
we clean.
Sweep the floors.
Our things from the floor 
pick up. 
Dump out
the trash.
It's nice and clean in here!
script_alutiiq_words:
Futii! Da-na-na-nah
Ugarpakartuq maani. Da-na-na-nah 
Tamamta Da-na-na-nah
pekcarau'ukut. Da-na-na-nah 

Cuumi nuus'hniit Da-na-na-nah 
p'rircarluki. Da-na-na-nah
Nat'ret kagiluki. Da-na-na-nah
Caqipet nategmek Da-na-na-nah
tuuluki. Da-na-na-nah
Kugyaturluki Da-na-na-nah
pumuuwiniit. Da-na-na-nah 
pritengia'artuq maani! (repeat 2nd stanza)
notes: This Camp Clean-Up Song 'Pee-yew' was created by the Dig Afognak Language and Music camp participants and Elders, 2013

script_english_words:
One, two, tie my shoe
Three, four, shut your door 
Five, six, pick up your sticks 
Seven, eight, put them like this 
Nine, ten, your fat hen
Let's stand up and count again!
script_alutiiq_words:
Allringuq, mal'uk, napyuusru pasmakiigka 
Pingayun, staaman, patugiu amiiran 
Talliman, arwilgen, tuugiu kenerkan 
Mallruungin, inglulgen, lliigiu tawaten 
Qulnguyan, qulen quilitsqaq kuuRican 
Nangarlita cali naaqilita!
notes: Translation of this popular English nursery rhyme

credit: Dig Afognak Language and Music Camp, 2013
script_english_words:
Let's all wake up in the morning. 
H ey-ah H ey-ah H ey-anga 
Let's all get up in the morning. 
H ey-ah H ey-ah H ey-anga 
Let's all have fun. 
H ey-ah H ey-ah H ey-anga 
Let's all go eat
While we laugh.
H ey-ah H ey-ah H ey-anga
script_alutiiq_words:
Esgarlita unuami.
H ey-ah H ey-ah H ey-anga
Maktlita unuami.
H ey-ah H ey-ah H ey-anga
Nunaniqsaagluta.
H ey-ah H ey-ah H ey-anga
Neryaturlita Englaryumaluta.
H ey-ah H ey-ah H ey-anga
notes: This Camp Walk Up Song - 'Let's Wake Up' was created by the Dig Afognak Language and Music camp participants and Elders, 2013

credit: Dig Afognak Language and Music Camp, 2013
script_english_words:
We love you all.
In the night. In the night. 
Let's all sleep well.
Let's be quiet. Let's be quiet.
script_alutiiq_words:
Qunukamci tamarpeci. 
Unugmi. Unugmi. 
Qawarlita asirluta. 
Nepainata. Nepainata.
notes: This Camp Sleep Song - 'Let's All Sleep ' was created by the Dig Afognak Language and Music camp participants and Elders, 2013

credit: Dig Afognak Language and Music Camp, 2013
script_english_words:
I'm hungry. I'm hungry. 
The bell is ringing.
I'm hungry. I'm hungry. 
Let's go. Let's go.

I'm hungry. I'm hungry. 
Our Elders are first.
I'm hungry. I'm hungry. 
What are you going to eat? 
I'm hungry. I'm hungry. 
They smell good, yeah! 
They are tasty.
script_alutiiq_words:
Kaigtua. Kaigtua. 
Kuluk'aunaq kaugaa. 
Kaigtua. Kaigtua. 
Kita! Kita!

Kaigtua. Kaigtua. 
Cuqllipet cuumi. 
Kaigtua. Kaigtua. 
Caqimek nerkutarcia? 
Kaigtua. Kaigtua. 
Tepkegtut, ayaa! 
Piturnirtut.
notes: This Meal Time Camp Song - 'I'm Hungry' was created by the Dig Afognak Language and Music camp participants and Elders, 2013

script_english_words:
How is the weather?
How is the weather?
How is the weather today?
Tell us, Johnny, tell us.
How is the weather today?
Is it sunny, cloudy, rainy today? Snowing, windy?
What is the weather like today?
script_alutiiq_words:
Cestun lla et'a?
Cestun lla et'a?
Cestun lla et'a ernerpak?
Niuskut, Johnny (name), niuskut.
Cestun lla et'a ernerpak?
Ili macanguq, qilanguq, qitenguq ernerpak? Qaninguq, aqllanguq?
Cestun lla et'a ernerpak?

title_english: On the Ocean with my Friends
script_english_words:
On the ocean by kayak,
On the ocean with my friend, 
On the ocean with my friend, 
On the ocean!

We are thankful on the ocean. 
We are thankful. It is sunny. 
We are thankful. It is sunny. 
We are thankful!

We see the eagle, 
We see. It fly. 
We see. It fly. 
We are seeing!
script_alutiiq_words:
Imarmi kayagun/kayakun, 
imarmi angayumeng-llu, 
imarmi angayumeng-llu, 
Imarmi!

Quyaukut imarmi. 
Quyaukut. Macanguq. 
Quyaukut. Macanguq. 
Quyaukut!

Tang'rtukut kum'agya(mek), 
Tang'rtukut. Tengaurtuq. 
Tang'rtukut. Tengaurtuq. 
Tang'rtukut!
notes: (Sing the 3 verses 2 times) Composed by participates of the Dig Afognak Music Camp 2012.

credit: Alisha Drabek, Florence Pestrikoff, Nick Alokli, Julia Naughton, Susan Malutin
script_english_words:
I have ten fingers (hold up both hands, fingers spread) 
They all belong to me, (point to self)
I do things with them (wiggle them back and forth) 
Do you want to see?

I close them (make fists)
I open them (open hands)
I put them together (place palms together) 
I hide them (put hands behind back)

I raise them up (hands over head)
I bring them down (touch floor)
I fold them up quietly (fold hands in lap) 
And hold them like so.
script_alutiiq_words:
Sua'angq'rtua qulenek 
Tamaita pinka 
Pit'anka 
Tangryuwaten?

Patuwanka
Ikirtanka
Lliiyanka allrilugmen 
Nuuyatanka

Qulwartanka 
Aciwartanka 
Im'gutanka nepaini 
Tuumiaqanka gwaten
notes: Ten Little Fingers,' Adapted from English nursery rhyme by Alisha Drabek, edited by Florence Pestrikoff, Nick Alokli, Julia Naughton, and Susan Malutin.
